subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA Keyboard layout
msgSnippet: In this context, logic is in the eye of the beholder. That s why I mentioned Spanish vowels earlier. For me, the fact that there is (nearly) a one-to-one
messageBody:
In this context, logic is in the eye of the beholder. That's why I
mentioned Spanish vowels earlier. For me, the fact that there is
(nearly) a one-to-one correspondence between Spanish vowels and
X-SAMPA made it easy for me to remember--this made it "logical". When
I took Spanish in junior high, my teacher drilled us on the
pronunciation of "a, e, i, o, u", saying "Ah, Ey, EE, Oh, OO" over and
over. And then again, over and over! And over and over! It's
impossible for me to forget it, decades later.

In order to become proficient with a new layout, we'll all have to
come up with some memory aids, many of them uniquely individual. If
you haven't studied Spanish, then of course my suggestion here will be
useless.

For me, QS-SAMPA is as logical as anything else, and since it follows
a useful standard wherever possible, it has the potential of becoming
a good standard for QS that is also accessible for newcomers.

Ted


It also depends on the background of the reader. Spanish is one of the la

> I understand a bit more now...... I didn't realise that S-SAMPA was
> prescriptive. I realise the value of following a standard, so I guess i
> will just have to get used to the illogicalities - or make my own keyboard,
> which I guess i will have to do!
>
> So long as the kerning is tight, there is no problem with creating the
> ligatures with the two letters and it will be useful to have the half
> letters.
>
> Paul, I didn't mean to demean the work you are doing. It is great stuff and
> I am sure the whole group is grateful for all the time and effort you are
> putting into it. If I had the expertise I would contribute more to it, but I
> dont.
>
> regards
>
> 
>
> PS What happened to the namer dot in ThothUni?
>

> On 08/12/2007, Ted Larson Freeman < freeman@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > Hi Moira,
> >
> > The assignments for 'If' and 'Eat' were swapped to conform to X-SAMPA.
> > Likewise, 'x' was assigned to 'Loch' and 'Q' to 'On' to conform to
> > X-SAMPA. The logical assignment for #36 is 'V', but we have two
> > letters, 'Ado' and 'Up'. John assigned 'y' to 'Ado' because it's nice
> > to have a lower-case assignment for such a frequently used letter,
> > leaving 'V' for the alternate 'Up'. That left 'q' as the only
> > remaining lower-case letter which I assigned to 'Noon', an alternate
> > that is used almost as often as 'Nun'. This leaves the upper case
> > letters 'B', 'C', 'F', 'L', 'M', and 'P'. Paul followed my original
> > suggestions in assigning some of these to ligatures. More recently,
> > Benct suggested assigning them to half-letters, and I found his ideas
> > compelling. But in any case, the assignment of half-letters and
> > ligatures is beyond the scope of the QS-SAMPA proposal. First things
> > first!
> >
> > Take another look at this:
> > http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAMPA_chart_for_English
> >
> > Ted
> >
> >
> > On Dec 8, 2007 6:30 AM, Moira O'Brien <mj@...> wrote:
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > Hello Ted
> > >
> > > Thanks for taking the time to make this detailed response. It was very
> > > useful to be able to review the key points in the discussion.
> > >
> > > I have been following the discussion with interest and have read all the
> > > posts on all three sites for the past 3 or 4 months. My main concerns
> are
> > > these:
> > >
> > > 1. That we have a "standardised" assignment of letters so that it does
> not
> > > matter whether we have your font or Paul's or Joe Blogg's font whatever
> is
> > > published is displayed correctly on everybody's computer.
> > >
> > > 2. The keyboard assignments are "logical". Some of the choices that
> appear
> > > to be made in QS-SAMPA do not appear to me to be logical. This is why I
> > > posted my last comments.
> > >
> > > 3. We establish, quickly, a standard font set that we can use to include
> in
> > > posts to the groups. At the moment if I include {  } in my message, I
> > > dont know if anyone can read it. On that point, if everyone used Anthony
> > > Grahn's excellent ThothUni typing tool then we can all represent QS
> letters
> > > in our posts. This will make them a lot more readable.
> > >
> > > I have been through the QS Sampa keyboard proposal in detail and while I
> can
> > > see the point of some of the choices there are others which puzzle me.
> For
> > > example, why swap If and Eat between "i" and "I". It makes little
> logical
> > > sense to me. Neither does taking away Exam from the "x" key. Also,  and
> 
> > > being on the "q" key makes them easy to remember. I know one can go on
> > > forever playing with these keyboard assignments but I guess at the end
> of
> > > the day one can learn anything. Does anyone else have any comments on
> this
> > > proposed layout?
> > >
> > > 
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > On 08/12/2007, Ted Larson Freeman < freeman@...> wrote:
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Hi Moira,
> > > >
> > > > Some of your questions have to do with QS-SAMPA, and some have to do
> > > > with the ThothSampa font, which does not yet include everything in the
> > > > QS-SAMPA proposal and which contains remnants of the earlier layout.
> > > > (For a font that does conform to QS-SAMPA, I suggest you try the font
> > > > "Junior Sampa no. 1", contained in the file "JuniorQSSAMPA1.ttf" in
> > > > the "Files->Fonts" folder for this group.)
> > > >
> > > > First, a few comments about QS-SAMPA. I'm not sure if you've read the
> > > > previous thread of messages about the proposal--if not I encourage you
> > > > to review them--and the files in the "Files->QS-SAMPA" folder. I'd
> > > > especially point out the file "qs_sampa.pdf", which lists the Jerome
> > > > and QS-SAMPA key assignments in the fourth and fifth columns. One of
> > > > the main reasons I made this proposal is that I'd like to make QS as
> > > > accessible as possible to professional linguists. This will be easier
> > > > if we move toward a standard notation that linguists already use.
> > > > Because we rely on the internet, it's also important to use ASCII
> > > > characters (just 7-bit ASCII, the first 128 characters). Further, I
> > > > wanted to use only upper and lower case letters to represent QS
> > > > letters so that punctuation marks and special symbols would be
> > > > available while typing QS.
> > > >
> > > > Wikipedia has good articles on SAMPA and X-SAMPA:
> > > > http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-SAMPA
> > > > http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAMPA_chart_for_English
> > > >
> > > > John Cowan provided the core of the proposal by going through X-SAMPA
> > > > and suggesting changes whenever X-SAMPA uses two letters for a QS
> > > > letter, or X-SAMPA assigns a non-letter (e.g. "@" or "{"), or QS
> > > > represents two sounds with one letter (QS #43 and #44). He explained
> > > > the differences from X-SAMPA in his message:
> > > > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/message/1538
> > > >
> > > > To round out the proposal, I added the assignments for the alternate
> > > > letters 'Noon' and 'Up' and for the naming dot and angled brackets.
> > > > (There has been some recent discussion about the naming dot, but for
> > > > now it's assigned to the backquote.) Six capital letters remain
> > > > unassigned.
> > > >
> > > > I agree that it will take some practice to get used to the new
> > > > assignments. We'll need to adopt a few new memory aids. For example,
> > > > you'll notice that the Spanish vowels "a, e, i, o, u" would be
> > > > represented in QS-SAMPA the letters by "A, e, i, o, u". (It's not
> > > > perfect, but it helped me.) And if you truly hate it, my offer stands
> > > > to create a customized keyboard layout for you.
> > > >
> > > > Ted
> > > >

> going

> > > > > font installed.
> > > > >
> > > > > I have a few issues on this layout. I would like to see more logical
> > > > > assignments for eg:
> > > > >
> > > > > 1. {Q} which for me should be on the 'O' key
> > > > > 2. {K} which logically should be on the 'K' key
> > > > > 3. Oil appears to be a duplicated on 'q' and 'R'
> > > > > 4. 'i' and 'I' have been swapped from Jerome. IMHO Jerome is more
> > > logical.
> > > > > 5. I can't see the namer dot in this keyboard.
> > > > >
> > > > > I am aware that I can design my own keyboard layout, but that is not
> as
> > > > > satisfactory in my opinion as arriving at more logical assignments.
> > > > >
> > > > > I find 12pt to be difficult to read though I can't fault your sizing
> > > > > compared to TO. The above is 16pt and is at a size that I find
> > > comfortable
> > > > > (and its not just because of my age lol).
